body: I can confirm now that installing boto3 together with mlflow would solve this particular bug at least for me and hopefully also for others.
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.

same problem here. 

I installed it manually and then asking me for a package called dateutil. I installed it manually again (pip3 install python-dateutil) and now getting this error:

botocore.exceptions.NoCredentialsError: Unable to locate credentials
Thank you for interacting with this issue! Removing the stale label!

@jmdinis What I noticed is that running with db configured solved my problem. The command that I used:

mlflow server \
    --backend-store-uri sqlite:///mlflow.db \
    --default-artifact-root file:///home/myuser/mlruns \
    --host 127.0.0.1
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.
Two minor releases later... This unmet dependency on `boto3` is still going on in `mlflow` v1.5, so it is increasingly looking like a feature.
Thank you for interacting with this issue! Removing the stale label!

rename.from: [BUG] Missing boto3 dependency in mlflow v1.3 python package
rename.to: [BUG] Missing boto3 dependency in mlflow python package

body: @mirekphd the lack of boto3 dependency in core MLflow is indeed intentional to keep the set of MLflow dependencies minimal. Note that you can `pip install mlflow[extras]` and boto3 will be installed. Closing for now, but feel free to reopen - thanks!
Having the same issue, I had to install manually boto3 on the client side.

How can I install manually boto3 on the client or the server side? Because I already tried all the pip, conda, update end etc kinds of ways to install boto3 on the virtual env created on conda, but It always appear that boto3 is not installed, but if I check the version, it is there!! 

(myenv) C:\RepositoriosGitLab\mlflow_ne_test>mlflow run examples/sklearn_elasticnet_wine_ne -P alpha=0.42
2021/02/09 15:40:57 INFO mlflow.projects.utils: === Created directory C:\Users\DEBORA~1.LOT\AppData\Local\Temp\tmpxmslboz0 for downloading remote URIs passed to arguments of type 'path' ===
2021/02/09 15:40:57 INFO mlflow.projects.backend.local: === Running command 'conda activate mlflow-004410b12f95e2e00831a0ba11ee1bfdc29d6f9d && python train.py 0.42 0.1' in run with ID '86fce21773314a06ad417ea061aa7efd' ===
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "train.py", line 11, in <module>
    import boto3, os, io
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'boto3'
2021/02/09 15:40:57 ERROR mlflow.cli: === Run (ID '86fce21773314a06ad417ea061aa7efd') failed ===


(myenv) C:\RepositoriosGitLab\mlflow_ne_test>conda list boto3
# packages in environment at C:\Users\debora.lott\Anaconda3\envs\myenv:
#
# Name                    Version                   Build  Channel
boto3                     1.9.66                   py37_0    anaconda

The solution for my problem was really simple, I just needed to add the library that I was trying to import as a dependence in the archive: **conda.yaml**. 
Previous of my modification the archive was: 

              name: tutorial
              channels:
                - defaults
              dependencies:
                - python=3.6
                - pip
                - pip:
                  - scikit-learn==0.23.2
                  - mlflow>=1.0

Now I just put boto3 in the end, turning it on this:

              name: tutorial
              channels:
                - defaults
              dependencies:
                - python=3.6
                - pip
                - pip:
                  - scikit-learn==0.23.2
                  - mlflow>=1.0
                  - boto3

End them, finally it works!
